Description: A narrow copper adze-blade: with a rounded butt, slightly concave sides, and a convex cutting edge. The edge has been sharpened by hammering and grinding from only one side of the blade.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Tomb of Djer, tomb O.31 subsidiary burial
Curator's comments: Bibliography: W. M. F. Petrie, 'Royal Tombs of the Earliest Dynasties' II, pl.VI, 23. For other examples of Early Dynastic round-topped adzes, see J. E. Quibell, 'Excavations at Saqqara, 1912-1914: Archaic Mastabas’ (Cairo, 1923), pl.VIII, 1; G. A. Reisner, 'The early dynastic cemeteries of Naga-ed-Dêr' I, (California, 1908), 115 and pl.40d; W. B. Petrie, 'Tombs of the courtiers and Oxyrhynkos' (London, 1925), pls.IV, 5, 7, 8; V, 19, 24:W. M. F. Petrie, 'Gizeh and Rifeh' (Warminster, 1977), pl.IIIA, top left; W. M. F. Petrie, 'Tarkhan I and Memphis V' (London, 1913), pls.V, 15, 25, 28, 29; J. Garstang, ‘Maḥâsna and Bêt Khallâf’ (London, 1989), pls.XVI, XXIII, XXIV; P. Montet, 'Kêmi' 8 (1946), pl.X; C. M. Firth and J. E. Quibell, 'Excavations at Saqqara : the Step Pyramid' II (Cairo, 1935), pl.93, (3); A. Petrie, 'Tarkhan I and Memphis V' (London, 1913), pl.V, 18-22; A. C. Mace in G. A. Reisner (ed.), 'The early dynastic cemeteries of Naga-ed-Dêr' II, (California, 1908), 47, fig. 107, (4) and pl.48a; J. de Morgan, ‘Recherches sur les Origines de l’Égypte (Paris, 1896-7), 251, fig. 838; 252, fig. 846; E.
